Q: Is there for people who perhaps feel depression or isolated, for the students is there a way to make them feel better or is something organized to help them, because it happens to young people who live far from their homes, their families...
A: Of course of course. For freshmen who are just starting the university there is this show called RealAD, like reality show, Real AD. And it's about all the struggles that students go through, created by upperclassmen for freshmen so that they see that, you know, many students actually don't understand what's going on in their classrooms. Many students misunderstand other cultures. Many students feel like everyone is smarter than them, you know, or many students miss home. BA1: There's counseling services and many events to connect and talk about your experiences.

Q: I have a question. How do you feel about being a woman in the UAE as a student?
A: In public places, like when I'm being served somewhere, food or something, I feel very respected when I go to a clinic or something. I'm very respected. I feel it's also because I'm white. Definitely, you know, they smile extra for me. But also at the same time there's this hardship every time a walk on the street, people really stare. Especially a South-Asian men. And it's just so hard. The other day I had someone pull up with a car and follow me slowly and tried to talk to me. And it doesn't matter what I wear, sometimes I also wear shorts, like back at home. But sometimes I decide, "You know what, today I don't want attention at all." I'm gonna wear long jeans and a long shirt - doesn't help. So it's this.. you know.. at home people stare as well, of course, everywhere, but they're a bit more subtle. You know if you look at them they look away. Here they just stare at you and you look at them and they continue.
BA1: I feel safe, but women here do get a lot of unwanted stares.

Q: Do you feel safe?
A: I feel very safe. I feel like my privacy is invaded and it just feels irritating and unfair all the time. But I feel way more safe. I mean, with the female seats on the bus where nobody can sit next to me and people leave me alone, that's wonderful, because even at home people would sit next to me on the bus and start talking to me and not get the point that I'm sitting alone for a reason. And at night I also feel very safe here. This is one of the safest countries in the world, it is very interesting, in a place where people invade your privacy so much it's also very safe in terms of crimes.
BA1: I feel safe, but women here do get a lot of unwanted stares.

Q: It's because they apply the law, that's why. That's the reason.... if they don't apply the law, how to be safe? Anyway... how... Every country has a different education system. So some countries they are more focused on academics, some other countries they are less focused on academics. This difference in the level... of the education level, how it is faced? Because you have what you attend the courses, the level I think that it must be similar and the material is similar. So how... What does the university do to adjust these differences between the knowledge of all the students? It's because they have to be in the same level to be able to attend the classes.
A: Well first of all they start with selecting the brightest students they can find from around the world and they're trying not to be too biased and select only from international programs, but they are a little bit biased because, you know, when someone has done some international schooling or some exchange program before, then they're more adapted and this is an indicator that they'll be successful here. I think you need to get until multivariable calculus for most majors. So you could be placed, in function and then you have like three different classes to take, or you can be placed in the next one - vectors, or in the next one calculus. If it's not a requirement for your major you do whatever you want, we don't care if you pass or fail, right. But if it's a requirement, you have to pass it.
BA1: The exams are decided by the professor of the class: how hard they are, how important they are and whether you have exams at all!

Q: And how the universities chooses the students? And how did you learn about this university?

Q: After your experience, in a multicultural environment, are there some things that you always do in the same way and some other things that you always avoid to do?
A: So I guess the thing that I always do in the same way is that I am not afraid to bring my own, like "this is how we do it at home and this is what I actually changed from on how we do it at home", and I'm open to what other people say and do at home, I'm very open.
